author: sky.cactus
content: My long term goals with the EIP process is to turn it into purely a technical specification process.  I have been pushing to get rid of everything related to mainnet inclusion, forking, etc. out of the EIPs process and just have it be a place where people can write very specific/targeted technical specifications.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially, it would only be part of the mainnet inclusion process as a side effect of "getting a technical spec drafted is a prerequisite for some other process", not because EIPs are the center of that process.

author: Deleted User
content: Yes, that would be a correct approach, I think

author: sky.cactus
content: Part of this, IMO, means getting rid of a lot of the debate, history, internal versioning, and even trimming down the motivation/rationale sections quite a bit for a lot of EIPs out there.  What really matters is the Specification section, and the other sections are only there to provide useful details for some distant future reader who wants to better understand the EIP.

author: sky.cactus
content: An EIP that just says, "set the gas cost of SSTORE to 500" would be totally valid without needing really much else, since that is sufficient for a technical changeset.

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe have a very brief statement about how 500 was calculated, but the EIP isn't necessarily the right place to put together a full defense argument.
